content:
As part of PhysLean, I am creating curated HTML notes for given topics. For example this one for the quantum harmonic oscillator.

The main component of these notes are the definitions, lemmas and theorems, which are created from the doc-string of the corresponding def, lemma or theorem in the Lean code. The definitions, lemmas and theorems actually given are from a curated list which show the overall story behind the formalization.To each one of these is a drop down option which shows the Lean code.

I am looking for ways to improve the structure of these notes. Ultimately I would like two things:

  1. Relevant words (e.g. names, tactics etc) should, on hovering your curser over them, give you their doc-string. Equivalent to what happens in The Lean Language Reference.
  2. The Lean code should be openable and runable in something like https://live.lean-lang.org.

How easy would something like 1 be to make? I don't really want to have to change the raw lean code or the way e.g. doc-string have to be written. Ideally I would want a function that takes in a name and an annotated (with html links or hoverables) version of the doc string and declaration string.

I believe 2 is much harder - and would require either something along these lines, or a dedicated server that allows you to import PhysLean into something like https://live.lean-lang.org, which I don't have the resources for.

Does anyone have any other suggestions of how things could be improved?

(I'm not here interested in the content of the notes - although if there is something within the content which could be improved there is a way to create an issue for a given e.g. definition etc within the notes)

Running a live-like server with your own setup isn't so hard or expensive, with a 30€ server per month you can already get very far, and even a more cheap one will work for a while, if you don't expect huge numbers of concurrent users. I can advise with setting it up.
As for 1 it seems you'd want to use verso, the tool behind the reference manual. Maybe you could use the reference manual setup as a starting point and adapt to your liking?
I'm itching to set up something like https://garnix.io/blog/garnix-modules for “Here is a lean project, with a few clicks I get a server running lean4web for it” so that anyone can easily host it.
